caption.text: In 1739 when the mission town was incorporated as Stockbridge, there was just one town. Over time as more white settlers moved to the area, they began to resent the involvement of the "Stockbridge Indians" in town government, and they petitioned for the creation of West Stockbridge. Both towns represented on the map were originally inhabited by the "Stockbridge Indians."
caption.title: The Two Stockbridges

caption.text: This map was created in 1855, about 70 years after the "Stockbridge Indians" left Massachusetts.

There are very few indications on this map that the indigenous people were ever there. In the Main Street close-up on the map you can see the "Indian Grant," "Indian Burial Place," and the "Indian Mission House."
caption.title: What Remained

caption.text: In the larger plan of Stockbridge, just under the Housatonic River, you can see designations for Konkapot's House and King Solomon's House. These are the only two indigenous names remaining in the town.
